Dipodomys spectabilis, commonly known as the banner-tailed kangaroo rat, is a species of rodent native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Heteromyidae, which includes kangaroo rats and pocket mice.

The banner-tailed kangaroo rat is a medium-sized rodent, typically measuring between 10 to 14 inches (25 to 36 cm) in total length, including a long, tufted tail that accounts for about half of the animal's total length. It has large hind legs and a small, slender body, adapted for bipedal locomotion and jumping. The fur is soft and silky, typically ranging in color from reddish-brown to grayish-brown on the upper parts, with white underparts.

This species is known for its complex, multi-chambered burrow systems, which can be up to 6 feet (1.8 m) deep and extend over an area of several hundred square feet. These burrows provide shelter, food storage, and nesting sites for the kangaroo rats. They are primarily nocturnal and granivorous, feeding on a variety of seeds, grains, and other plant materials.

Dipodomys spectabilis is well-adapted to the arid and semi-arid environments of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico, where it plays an important role in the ecosystem as a seed disperser and prey for various predators, such as coyotes, hawks, and snakes.
